fields.headline: European round-up  Mark Tallentire
fields.bodyText: Denmark gained a deserved 1-0 win in the match against Norway thanks to an early goal from Jesper Gronkjaer and moved to the top of Group Two, a result made all the more satisfying following their 2-0 defeat at home to Bosnia in April. The Chelsea winger was put clear by Charlton's Claus Jensen before shooting low past the goalkeeper. Denmark, who now have 10 points and lead the Norwegians by virtue of a superior head-to-head record, next play in Luxembourg on Wednesday. "Obviously we need three points then but the pressure is on Norway," said Morten Olsen, the Danish coach Romania , who visit Norway that same evening, beat Bosnia 2-0 to move into third place on nine points. The shock of the weekend came in Zaragoza where Greece inflicted a first home qualifier defeat on Spain , the Group Six leaders, since France beat them 2-1 in October 1991. Stelios Giannakopoulos got the goal with a 20-yard drive three minutes before half-time of a match the hosts dominated, the more so after Greece were reduced to 10 men in the 82nd minute. Ukraine grabbed a 4-3 injury-time win over Armenia , who led twice, leaving the group wide open with the Ukrainians and Greece, who meet in Athens on Wednesday, a point behind Spain, who face Northern Ireland. "Now it is vital to go to Belfast and get a good win," said Inaki Saez after his first defeat as the Spanish coach. The match between the top two in Group Ten finished 2-2 in Basle but only after Russia fought back from 2-0 down against Switzerland . The unbeaten Swiss stay top, on nine points, ahead of Russia and Ireland, both with seven. Austria , joint hosts of Euro 2008 with the Swiss, went down 1-0 in Moldova - who had lost all four or their Group Three qualifiers - and now look out of it on six points, four behind the Czechs and seven behind Holland , who won 2-0 in Belarus where Patrick Kluivert became the Dutch all-time leading scorer with 38, one more than Dennis Bergkamp.
